text: lappa lux that's all she hi everyone
Anthony Fantan over here Internet's
busiest music nerd and it's time for a
review of the new lappa Lux LP nostalgic
lappa Lux is an electronic music
producer based in the UK I first ran
into his music last year through an EP
that came out early in the year titled
when you're gone came out on brain
feeder records and this new full-length
album of his which he has worked up the
courage to assemble and release is also
on brain feeder records now when you're
gone compiled a bunch of different
electronic music styles together current
electronic music styles like wonky as
well as future garage maybe a slight
baby itty-bitty bit of R&B and
stylistically it was just a little
inconsistent kind of jumping around all
over the place AZ and a handful of
tracks on this EP I thought were
produced maybe a little too densely to
the point where nothing really stuck out
in terms of a groove or a melody or
really anything interesting because
there are so many interesting things are
just so many very good sounds all sort
of buzzing at once I thought that this
new album and when you're gone it's
maybe not a night and day difference it
was maybe more of like a night and Dawn
difference the biggest change on this
new collection of tracks lappa Lux
organizes his sounds so much better on
this LP resulting in most of these songs
sounding much more well orchestrated
there are clear grooves awesome synth
variations that come through and
translate very well and what's also
awesome is that this album seems to kind
of pile on even more genres of music and
still manages to come through sounding
pretty good not too disjoint it or
anything like that because a good couple
of tracks on this thing embrace a very
awesome alternative R&B sound and the
overall result on this record is just an
album that sounds blissful psychedelic
there is one
though on this LP that caught me as
being sort of lappa lux letting his
maximal tendencies kind of get the best
of him the song Kelly broke it catches
my attention definitely with how dense
it is but I'm still not sure what to
make of the song really with all the
pitch shifted vocals on this thing and
the slow synth funk melodies it does
feel oddly sexy but I still can't help
but feel like I'm listening to some kind
of vapor wave bastardization of the soul
glow add jingle another track that kind
of kicks off this LP a track that was
dropped before this LP came out girl it
kind of brings the title of this album
home the Stahl chic it's definitely got
an 80s vibe to it I felt almost a Peter
Gabriel toto kind of thing coming from
the synthesizers with the way that they
were shaped in terms of a groove and
just the tone of them the sound of them
but still has a song the beat a
progression the sequence it doesn't
really hook me it doesn't really grab me
honestly this song kind of had me not
anticipating that much from this LP when
I first heard it aside from a very
pretty opener on this album a nostalgic
is kind of off to a rocky start
thankfully it gets pretty awesome pretty
quick right after these songs the song
one thing which has a vocal contribution
from Jana Andrews is an awesome track
and awesomely smooth and sensual
psychedelic R&B flavored slow jam not
only does he make space for her very
beautiful and emotive voice on this song
but he surrounds it in sounds that make
it feel like it's from an entirely
different solar system I actually think
the aura the sonic aura this track
rivals some moments on the one-and-only
kozma grandma there's another R&B
flavored track later on the LP with
Carrie Latham on vocals and while it is
not as Spacey or as I guess
intergalactic it's a little more serene
and subdued it's really kind of the same
strengths but on an entirely different
track and with some interesting future
garage inspired vocal cuts sort of
peppered throughout the song and yes on
this album once again future garage
music does show up as a prime influence
but I feel like honest
Shiekh lappa Lux does a better job of
combining it with his sort of brain
feeder records nature and style because
on the song flower you get these burial
s focal cuts and chops against this very
thick weird bass heavy walk EB and the
vocal melody on this thing is absolutely
earner infectious and lappa looks pretty
much trips through this album
consistently with different variations
of this wonky future garage combo along
with some slower prettier vocal led jams
but he brings a few more surprises
toward the end of the LP the song
walking worlds on this album is is
easily just some synthesizer led art pop
I love the electric piano on this track
the way it skips along on the groove and
the very shy vocals with the melody that
they're singing that seems very lullaby
esque there's also some vocals on the
outro track on this thing as well which
brings up another surprise with sort of
an acoustic guitar right at the start of
the song that sounds like it was
recorded on like a tape recorder or
something there's a bit of a tape hum
and lap luck starts to chop up all of
these chunks of the guitar playing and
the the vocals whether it be during the
take that I'm hearing or through some
other take that was recorded later in
this vocal recording with the guitar and
he turns it into a beat itself and it's
a fantastically cinematic closer overall
I really liked this LP I thought it was
easily and improvement past what lap
looks did on when you're gone last year
not only is it more consistent all the
influences that he takes on are brought
together in a more interesting and
unique away most of the vocal led tracks
on this album are fantastic really great
intros and outros just a lot of
highlights still there are a few issues
on this thing with consistency coming
together with tracks that actually feel
like standouts instead of just filler
I'm pretty much feeling a light - decent
seven on this thing if you've given it a
listen what did you think of it did you
love it did you hate it why what do you
think I should review next
and yeah that's it
nostalgic forever
